meanings.def: used to say that something has been removed or become separated
examples: He's had his beard shaved off.
Take your coat off.
The label must have fallen off.
Don't leave the toothpaste with the top off.

meanings.def: not connected or functioning
examples: The water is off.
Make sure the TV is off.

meanings.def: away from a place; at a distance in space or time
examples: I called him but he ran off.
He fell off a ladder and broke his arm.
Sarah's off in India somewhere.
I must be off (= I must leave) soon.
Summer's not far off now.
A solution is still some way off.
Off you go! Enjoy yourselves!

meanings.def: away from work or duty
examples: She's off today.
I've got three days off next week.
How many days did you take off?
I need some time off.

meanings.def: starting a race
examples: They're off (= the race has begun).

meanings.def: taken from the price
examples: shoes with $20 off
All shirts have/are 10 per cent off.

meanings.def: no longer going to happen; cancelled
examples: The wedding is off.

meanings.def: no longer available or being served
examples: Sorry, the duck is off.

meanings.def: behind or at the sides of the stage in a theatre
to be in a better or worse situation
examples: She's better off without him.
The weather was so bad we'd have been better off staying at home.
We can't be any worse off than we are already.

meanings.def: to have a particular amount of something
examples: How are we off for coffee (= how much do we have)?

meanings.def: used to say how much money somebody has
examples: Families will be better off under the new law (= will have more money).
They are both comfortably off (= have enough money to be able to buy what they want without worrying too much about the cost).

meanings.def: from time to time; now and again
examples: It rained on and off all day.

idioms.def: to be in a better or worse situation
examples: She's better off without him.
The weather was so bad we'd have been better off staying at home.
We can't be any worse off than we are already.

idioms.def: to have a particular amount of something
examples: How are we off for coffee (= how much do we have)?

idioms.def: used to say how much money somebody has
examples: Families will be better off under the new law (= will have more money).
They are both comfortably off (= have enough money to be able to buy what they want without worrying too much about the cost).

idioms.def: from time to time; now and again
examples: It rained on and off all day.

meanings.def: down or away from a place or at a distance in space or time
examples: I fell off the ladder.
Keep off the grass!
an island off the coast of Spain
They were still 100 metres off the summit.
Scientists are still a long way off finding a cure.
We're getting right off the subject.

meanings.def: used to say that something has been removed
examples: You need to take the top off the bottle first!
I want about an inch off the back of my hair.

meanings.def: away from work or duty
examples: He's had ten days off school.

meanings.def: away from a price
examples: They knocked £500 off the car.

meanings.def: leading away from something, for example a road or room
examples: We live off Main Street.
There's a bathroom off the main bedroom.

meanings.def: from a person or place
examples: I got this off a website somewhere.

meanings.def: off; from
examples: She jumped off of the wall.
I got it off of my brother.

meanings.def: not wanting or liking something that you usually eat or use
examples: I'm off (= not drinking) alcohol for a week.
He's finally off drugs (= he no longer takes them).

meanings.def: no longer fresh enough to eat or drink
examples: This fish has gone off.
The milk smells off.
It's off.
I think this milk is slightly off.

meanings.def: not polite or friendly
examples: He was a bit off with me this morning.

meanings.def: not acceptable
examples: It's a bit off expecting us to work on Sunday.

meanings.def: the start of a race
examples: They're ready for the off.

meanings.def: to kill somebody
not on; away from
examples: offstage
offload
